Now the White House of Trump Maps the Statue of Freedom
The safest sign of regime change is to start attacking the statues .
The Americans appreciate this as well as any other - hence the carefully staged overthrow of Saddam Hussein at Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , certainly knew what he did when he included a symbolic axe on the Statue of Liberty in a heated dispute with CNN ’ s Jim Acosta about the president ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A horde of boat owners and liberty imitators would have lynched him if he had done so .

But he attacked their importance , and in particular the importance that was attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
When Miller Acosta insulted , " I don 't want to go into a complete thing about history , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that enlightens the world .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original statue of freedom . '
Miller is right , but , as he himself said , it is not really about history .

It is a question of contemporary resonance to the upsetting words of Lazarus , the only one in which a state invites not only any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your tiredness , your poor , / your crowds that are longing for breathing freely , / the miserable waste of your rich coasts ' .
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' on our screens was better to see .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict , because of the importance of a statue , is part of a broader political and cultural debate : it is indeed a conflict over the importance of America .
Lazarus - and her friends who worked to place their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they were doing a highly political act .
The sculpture was supposed to show the links between French and American Republicanism by portraying the female embodiment of freedom in a disguised classic picture .
Lazarus changed this meaning : In her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a completely different name : Mother of Exilants .
The combination of the poem with the picture is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people from the right wing wanted to change it for a long time .

The great shrine of Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Freedom was not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative who would bring the American flame into the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It is supposed to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch should not illuminate the way to the United States . '
Limbaugh was quite unusual here .
The meaning of the statue is quite a question of the point of view of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see it as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
It is truly a question of seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Her statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome they must hear .
And that , of course , is not the prospect that Miller and Trump would ever like to acknowledge .
Their torch is not intended to illuminate the way , but to inflame the hatred that is its only source of power .

Poverty and Death in the Indonesian Goldland
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a cooker .
It rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai regency in the unsettled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the bowl is taken and swallowed with diligent , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the clay floor - she does not have furniture - where she also performs her daily work , such as washing clothes with clouds from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of the four wives of her husband , she was not assigned .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , working late can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around in the village after 5 p.m. ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony that was admitted in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were to vote by a public rally before the occupying forces .

An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is deserted .
There is no public transport .
The town , with about 19,000 inhabitants , consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated roofs converted into different yellow brown tones by rust .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wear this clothing ,  says Degei and indicates her vibrant , handwoven turban , her dark shirt and her bright rock .
'In the past , we had only leaves on our bodies ' .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s goldland .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Phoenix Freeport McMoran , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a high land province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , freeport amounted to $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has timber resources worth an estimated $ 78 billion .
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papua , ensuring that Indonesia ’ s powerful military retains a stifling presence .

A 2005 investigation in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid nearly $ 20 million to local military personnel and units between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten these golden gans and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal highlands in the 1970 ’ s became genocide under the Asian Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We shall all lose  is said in a 2016 report by the Archdiocese of Brisbane , which contains reports of atrocities of the previous year , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electrical strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal repression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims as events happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesia researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have increased as Papua ’ s resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic development is changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanesian warnings canteens sell fried chicken and gado-gado , served a mixed vegetable with peanut sauce .
Local people are fighting to keep up here .

'It has cost the local Papua - the Mama Mama [ the women ] of Papua - their market . '
Indonesian President Joko Widodo , known as Jokowi in the popular mouth , promised to address inequalities and violations in Papua during his 2014 campaign .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the 29 districts of Papua - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today the locals feel cheated .
Our hearts have broken because we voted in favour of Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says you .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai suffered a low point .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children was out there and sang Christmas songs before a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the darkness on a motorcycle .
The frightened children told them that they should turn their headlights on .
One of the soldiers took up their tone and later returned with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their guns , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , the 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was beaten so hard that he fell into coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was burnt in fire , and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women and children gathered in a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military command centre to demand justice .
They performed ceremonial hunting arches and performed the Waita dance - running in circles and imitating a bird song - by Papuas Mee Pago Stamm .
Some protesters began to throw stones on police and military posts .

When the mood was heated , the soldiers were sent a command over an internal radio : " If the masses resist more than three times , they shoot them dead , " says a TIME official document that was not released to the local media .
Yeremias Kayame , 56 , the head of the Kego Koto district of Enarotali , saw the threat and called for peace and asked the crowd to return home .
Nobody was listening to the mood .

If the balance tends too far towards inflammation , it may result in inflammatory intestinal disease .
Experiments found that a kind of tolerant immune cell occurs in mice that carries a particular bacterium in its initials .
